translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)🔽The Chapter of the Hen

analyzed: paṇṇaka jātaka  paṇṇakam tikhiṇadhāra  asim sampanna pāyina
translated: The Birth Story of Paṇḍaka (1)
“A man who swallows a sword
With a sharp blade and a good hilt,🔽What is more difficult than that?🔽Tell me, when asked,
What other difficult thing there is.”

analyzed: gileyya purisaḥ lobhā  asim sampanna pāyina
translated: “A man who swallows a sword🔽Out of greed,

analyzed: yā u ca vajjā dadāmi iti
translated: And then says, ‘I’ll give you a reward,’
That’s more difficult than that.
Knowing all, it’s an easy thing,
So know it, gentle sir.”
“Āyura answered the question,
Skilled in the meaning of the Teaching.
Now I ask Pukkusa,
What is more difficult than that?🔽Tell me, when asked,
What other difficult thing there is.”

analyzed: na vācam upajīvanti  aphalam giram udīrita
translated: “They don’t live on words,🔽A statement without fruit.
But one who gives and then regrets it,
That’s more difficult than that.
Knowing all, it’s an easy thing,
So know it, gentle sir.”
“Pukkusa answered the question,
Skilled in the meaning of the Teaching.
Now I ask Senaka,
What is more difficult than that?
“What is the most difficult thing?
Please tell me that, when asked.”
“If a man were to give a gift,
whether it be little or much,

analyzed: yaḥ ca da tvā na anutappe
translated: And if he were not to regret it,
That is more difficult than that.
‘All-knowing’ is an easy thing,
Know that, Maddava.”
“Āyur explained the question,
Then the man Pukkusāti,
He answered all the questions,
Just as Senaka spoke.”
The Paṇḍavagāthā is the sixth.
